revised_title: Observations on the Color and Appearance of Jupiter\'s Belts
tldr: John Phillips, a geology professor, shares his observations of Jupiter\'s belts through his equatorial telescope. He describes the belts as appearing ochraceous, or similar to the color of some sand or "red" deal wood. He also notes that the outer borders of the equatorial bands are not parallel and that there is no similar tint on the moon or Mars. Phillips suggests that the colored extra-equatorial belts may be land seen between white clouds.
